main ‚Üê sullystuff:clean-fork

Thanks for your feedback, @kernoelpanic. It's great to see one of the authors of‚Ä¶ the paper acknowledging some of the limitations with the approaches that have been presented. The assumption that delivery receipts are mostly unnecessary couldn't be further from the truth. The reality is that they serve several important functions that significantly *enhance* security, and they are a crucial feature that users expect to work as quickly and reliably as possible. The vast majority of delivery receipts on Signal are sent as end-to-end encrypted messages that are completely opaque to the service. If you know someone's [profile key](https://signal.org/blog/signal-profiles-beta/), and are therefore able to exchange messages with them using [sealed sender](https://signal.org/blog/sealed-sender/), then you can also send each other delivery receipts that look just like normal e2ee message traffic. One of the hallmark features of the Signal Protocol is that message keys "ratchet" forward, with each message [encrypted by a new and unique key](https://signal.org/docs/specifications/doubleratchet/). Because delivery receipts can be encapsulated in a standard Signal message, just like a handcrafted reply, they can also advance the ratchet. This is a substantial improvement that enables key material to rotate far more frequently than it would otherwise. In the case of transient errors, Signal clients can also ask each other to re-send a message that wasn't delivered successfully. The delivery receipts act as an important checkpoint in this context. Once a message has been delivered, the client can safely ignore any requests to re-deliver the same message. Dropping delivery receipts "for actions that do not trigger observable notifications" (for example, a reaction to someone else's message in a group chat) would make this entire line of defense far more complicated and error-prone. In the case of a fast-moving conversation, a delay of up to 5 seconds before delivery receipts are sent would negatively affect the perceived and actual performance of the app in ways that would harm the user experience and that could lead people to choose less secure alternatives. In order to maximize battery life, mobile platforms place extraordinary limitations on the amount of background processing that apps can perform. Introducing randomized client-side delays could easily result in situations where background processes are killed by the OS before a delivery receipt can be sent. Those receipts could be delayed until additional messages are received (and therefore the app gets another limited execution window) or held up until the app is launched into the foreground. Whenever those situations inevitably occurred, the sender would perceive Signal as being broken and slow. It simply isn't a tenable suggestion, from either a UX or technical perspective. Introducing these delays on the server-side doesn't address the UX issues at all, and as people have already pointed out in this thread it could increase the scope of the metadata that's stored on the service which is something we don't want to do. The Signal service strives to retain as little metadata as possible, and also goes to great lengths to avoid having access to any sensitive information in the first place. The only way to do this is for the app to process end-to-end encrypted messages directly on your own device instead of our servers. Regarding potential "Resource Exhaustion Attacks" via delivery receipts in Signal, we think it's important to emphasize this quote from the paper: > For Signal, we were not able to considerably drain the battery of our testing phone (iPhone 13 Pro). Due to considerably stricter rate limits, it only decreased by 1% after an hour of attack. Many of our competitors store plaintext messages in a database, and they can send message content directly to Apple and Google for efficient push notification delivery that requires zero background processing on your phone. You don't need to wake up an app to decrypt a message if it wasn't encrypted to begin with. These apps will never be mentioned in any papers discussing end-to-end-encrypted delivery receipts and resource exhaustion, but that doesn't make them more secure. Quite the opposite. For people who want to restrict delivery receipts, Signal already supports disabling phone number discoverability (Settings > Privacy > Phone Number > Who Can Find Me By Number). With this setting enabled, you can choose a random alphanumeric username and no one will be able to send you any messages (delivery receipts or otherwise) unless you share that username with them.

Thank you, @greyson-signal, for your detailed comment. I strongly encourage c‚Ä¶ontinued discussion on this topic, as it's clear that there is no simple, ‚Äúsilver bullet‚Äù solution. I‚Äôd like to break down the necessity of delivery receipts again in more detail to ensure everyone (especially me üôÇ) is on the same page. Please correct me if I‚Äôm misunderstanding anything: **1. First, argument for delivery reciepts:** > they can also advance the ratchet. This is a substantial improvement that enables key material to rotate far more frequently than it would otherwise. If we assume that every message triggers exactly one delivery receipt, this increases key-material rotation by a constant factor of two. While this is indeed more frequent, I don't think it represents a substantial improvement, especially not one that would meaningfully degrade protocol security if absent. Especially, since conversations in which no messages are exchanged will stall key rotation regardless; if no messages are sent, no messages can be acknowledged by delivery receipts. So the lack of key rotation in these ‚Äúlow-volume‚Äù conversations should be a greater concern than the incremental improvement gained by doubling rotation frequency in active ones due to delivery receipts. **2. Second argument for delivery reciepts:** > In the case of transient errors, Signal clients can also ask each other to re-send a message that wasn't delivered successfully. The delivery receipts act as an important checkpoint in this context. Once a message has been delivered, the client can safely ignore any requests to re-deliver the same message. Dropping delivery receipts "for actions that do not trigger observable notifications" (for example, a reaction to someone else's message in a group chat) would make this entire line of defense far more complicated and error-prone. The basic argument here seems to be: Without delivery receipts, corner cases become more complex. I agree‚Äîthis is probably true, and additional complexity is never ideal, especially since complexity is the natural enemy of security. But this is exactly why I appreciate this conversation: perhaps there‚Äôs a better solution? Right now, delivery receipts acknowledge the happy path, where clients confirm successful receipt and decryption. But as you pointed out, what the protocol really needs to handle well are the unhappy path scenarios where receipt or decryption fails. However, since delivery receipts can simply be withheld by a malicious client, they do not provide strong protection against repeated re-delivery requests. Am I misunderstanding something here? Wouldn‚Äôt it make more sense to design robust logic specifically for transient- error handling and re-delivery requests, rather than acknowledging every message in the happy path? Maybe I am wrong, and delivery receipts are the best solution. If that‚Äôs the case, then the key question becomes: What are the privacy tradeoffs, and are they worth it?

It‚Äôs clear that there is no easy solution/quick-fix, but personally I hope at least the discussion continues between Signal and the paper author(s), even if in private and it still ends with no viable mitigations being discovered/implemented.

If there really is no way to mitigate this without degrading security, then I feel like security should come first and one should 1) trust one‚Äôs contacts and 2) enable phone number privacy (PNP) and optionally set a difficult to guess username. But I‚Äôm hoping that something can at least partially mitigate this or that there is an acceptable middle ground that doesn‚Äôt measurably or practically (and preferably also theoretically, but that might be asking too much) degrade security.

main ‚Üê sullystuff:clean-fork

@kernoelpanic > If we assume that every message triggers exactly one delivery‚Ä¶ receipt, this increases key-material rotation by a constant factor of two. While this is indeed more frequent, I don't think it represents a substantial improvement, especially not one that would meaningfully degrade protocol security if absent. Just some background: the Signal Protocol uses a double-ratchet algorithm (well, now with the post-quantum stuff, more like a triple-ratchet). You can read more about it [here](https://signal.org/docs/specifications/doubleratchet/), but there is a very real benefit to having frequent _bi-directional_ messaging. The TL;DR is that if Alice sends 100 messages in a row with no response, those message all live on the same "chain" and could be decrypted with the same key material in a compromise scenario. But when Bob replies, you start a whole new ratchet, and a whole new chain. This is where Signal's forward-secrecy comes from. This is why it is, indeed, very beneficial to have client-sent delivery receipts. You have much shorter message chains, even when only one side is initiating message sends. > Especially, since conversations in which no messages are exchanged will stall key rotation regardless; if no messages are sent, no messages can be acknowledged by delivery receipts. So the lack of key rotation in these ‚Äúlow-volume‚Äù conversations should be a greater concern than the incremental improvement gained by doubling rotation frequency in active ones due to delivery receipts. Not exactly clear what you're saying here. If no messages are sent, then there's nothing to be compromised? Like, if two people don't talk for a year, that's ok. You don't need to be ratcheting key material for messages that aren't sent. You'll ratchet the next time you _do_ send. > However, since delivery receipts can simply be withheld by a malicious client, they do not provide strong protection against repeated re-delivery requests. Am I misunderstanding something here? The system for recovering from decryption errors and resending messages is too complex to explain in a single comment, but if a client is configured to never send delivery receipts, sure, they could request the message again later one time (with how the system works). That's not the concern. The concern would be someone getting access to all of a user's key material, but not their messages, and then being able to request all the messages to be resent to them. If the target in question has a normal client with normal delivery receipt behavior, then this greatly mitigates what an attacker could do. The long and short of it is, that if we decided not to send delivery receipts for those messages, we'd also have to stop making those messages resendable, which would be a UX regression that we don't want to make. We understand that Signal cannot be everything to everybody. If people are concerned about this, as previously mentioned, you can disable discovery in the settings. If someone's threat model includes concerns about network activity _in general_ (because let's be clear, there are many other potential vectors to consider depending on your specific threat model), we recommend using a VPN. Hopefully this is helpful. I wanted to respond to your initial concerns and explain why the approach that was suggested in this pull request wouldn't work. But we don't typically use GitHub for these types of discussions. https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#github-is-not-a-generic-discussion-forum

Comment by greyson-signal - Anti timing attack features

main ‚Üê sullystuff:clean-fork

@Whatnoww > It's expected that for Signal Connections, the server wouldn't b‚Ä¶e able to stop delivery receipts, but for non-Signal connections, where the server is always the one generating the delivery receipt (due to the attacker not having a profile key), there could be some work done to throttle it there, and would probably substantially reduce these type's of attacks, since most Signal users aren't communicating with threat actors that are trying to track device usage via delivery receipts. You'll be happy to know that _sending_ non-sealed-sender messages is pretty heavily rate-limited already. Has been for the past year or two. I agree that with you that this should already mitigate most of the concern here, for the reasons you've mentioned. @kernoelpanic > even when no new messages are sent, the previously sent message(s) (even those deleted via disappearing messages) remain susceptible to recovery if an attacker recorded them in transit and the key material is subsequently compromised. Because of the double-ratcheting, only the messages on the most recent chain could be decrypted, and the ratcheting you get from delivery receipts makes these chains 1 message long in the common case. Removing the delivery receipts would substantially increase the length of the average chain. > As mentioned in my initial post, this could be mitigated by implicitly acknowledging all previously unacknowledged messages whenever an explicit reply is sent. At that point, all earlier messages can be treated as delivered, and retransmission can be restricted. Just because a user has sent you a message afterwards doesn't mean they successfully-decrypted all previously-received messages. A sender could have sent a single bad message in the past, and there's other catalysts for key rotation that can occur besides receiving replies, resulting in situations where you can decrypt more recent messages from a user but not older ones. > If the goal is to eliminate end-to-end delivery receipts entirely, one approach would be to only have delivery receipts between the client and the server. Server-managed delivery receipts are not possible when using [Sealed Sender](https://signal.org/blog/sealed-sender/), which represents the vast majority of message traffic. The server does not know who the sender was, and therefore cannot provide a delivery receipt. > The sender would receive a receipt from the server confirming that the message was stored. Maybe the term "receipt" is getting overloaded here -- just getting a 200 from the server for your message send implies that the message was stored, no additional receipt is necessary for that information. > The server would then retain the message until it receives a delivery receipt from the client that the message was received. Under this approach, messages cannot be silently lost. This is effectively what happens today. The receiver pulls messages from their message queue, acking each message they received so that the server knows they can discard it. > If a decryption error occurs at the receiver the client has to request retransmission anyway with a dedicated message. Indeed, and they have to request re-encryption from the sender, since whatever was sent to them before could not be decrypted. At the end of this suggestion I'm left a little confused: this doesn't just eliminate "end-to-end delivery receipts", it eliminates any concept of a delivery receipt as it exists in the app today. Like, the sender can't know when the receiver actually received their message. We have no intention of removing the concept of delivery receipts from Signal. If the point of this suggestion was just to show that it's theoretically possible to build an app without delivery receipts, sure, not saying it's impossible, just that we would find the compromises unacceptable. I still hold that if people are concerned about these types of issues, they're better off changing Who Can Find Me By Number > Nobody and/or using a VPN. I do appreciate the suggestions! I don't want people to feel like we're not listening, which is why I'm doing my best to respond point-by-point. But I don't currently see us making any changes in this area right now for the reasons I've given. > I am happy to continue the discussion on the community forum as suggested. Is there a preferred place to post this, or is there an existing thread on the topic? You can create a topic here: https://community.signalusers.org/c/general/7

I don‚Äôt understand, why this thread is marked with a green tick. The problem is not solved. It‚Äôs only explained, why the problem exists. I think it should only be tacked as solved, if the problem is solved, but not, if the reason for the problem is explained.

And by the way: the solution would be so simple:
Just ignore unknown packages, that don‚Äôt have the correct Signal-format and/or are from unknown senders. Or messages, that even aren‚Äôt displayed. By the way: people who are not in my contact-list / verified by me, that I want to communicate with them, don‚Äôt need to and should get no information, if I received a message.

Threema had the same problem in the past. And they solved it. Why doesn‚Äôt Signal solve it this way? Or any other way that works, as long as it is solved. Because this is no minor bug, but a very big problem for a privacy-concerned messenger, if attackers can get my location.

And it goes even further:
if they see, that I only have the same location on workdays from 9-5, they know with 99%, that this is the place I work. And if they see, that I often have the same location at nights or on weekends, they know with 99%, that this is the place where I live / where my house is.

That‚Äôs a very big problem. And how can I recommend Signal to others and argue with privacy, if attackers, who know how to do, can see the location of any Signal-user. And even see, where every Signal-user lives and works.
